newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenian SBI index eases, seen biding time.
newsitem.headline: Slovenian SBI index eases, seen biding time.

text.p: Slovenia's SBI share index eased for the third trading day on Tuesday and traders said the lack of foreign demand was likely to keep trading activity at a low ebb until September.
"Now we are facing a typical summer standstill. In September, when foreigners are expected to return, volumes and prices will increase," said Ales Novak, a trader at brokerage Ilirika.
The SBI index eased 0.35 percent or 5.60 points to 1,581.54.
Market participants said foreign activity is subdued as buyers seem to be waiting for prices to fall.
"Why should they (the foreigners) come to our market when they know that the market will come to them -- they know that they will be able to buy cheaper after a while," one broker said.
Overall 11 shares fell, eight rose and one was flat while eight were untraded. Turnover rose to 172.6 million tolars from 113.8 million.
Port operator Luka Koper was the most actively traded stock, falling 1.83 percent to 2,140 tolars on volume of 4,426 shares.
Issue C of drug maker Lek led decliners, tumbling 5.43 percent to 33,100 tolars on volume of only one share.
Brokerage Dadas was the top gainer, rising 3.68 percent to 9,010 tolars on volume of 123 shares.
Market participants said drug producer Lek and petrol trader Petrol were the leading shares on the market and would probably attract the eye of investors when foreign capital returns.
Lek closed 1.55 percent lower at 35,510 tolars on volume of 1,011 shares for total turnover of 36.2 million tolars.
Petrol eased 0.84 percent to 24,800 tolars on volume of 2,249 shares.
